awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Adaptive Building Enclosure Systems Using Cellular Solid-Solid Phase Change Materials with Variable Transparency
awd_abstract_narration:
Buildings are responsible for about 40 percent of US energy consumption; a significant fraction of this energy is consumed to counter thermal losses or gains occurring through building envelopes. Passive-solar-design seeks to balance heat loss through the building envelope with solar energy input, while also using thermal mass, shading, and/or ventilation to dampen daily thermal swings. However, implementation of current passive-solar-design tends to be highly context-specific and often entails use of costly mechanical devices and controls.  This project aims to study an innovative passive solar building enclosure system that uses cellular solid-solid phase change materials (SS-PCM) with variable transparency. The system relies on passive material-enabled controls and has no mechanically moving parts or electrical components. Successful implementation of SS-PCM foam-based building envelope materials can result in low cost responsive building enclosure systems that self-regulate building thermal comfort. The outcome of this study can lead to new technologies that reduce energy use in buildings, decrease dependence on fossil fuels, and improve the economic competitiveness of the United States. This study is also expected to result in benefits to diverse industries such as building materials, construction, and energy conservation. An innovative outreach plan will be implemented in the form of a competition that engages students at various levels of education in the topics of passive solar design, energy use, and thermal comfort in buildings.

The goal of this project is to uncover the fundamental principles that govern the behavior of translucent cellular SS-PCM systems used in realistic building envelopes. Fundamental insights will be gained on (1) heat transfer phenomena occurring in SS-PCM foam systems, (2) the synergistic effects occurring between three material-enabled solar-light irradiation control mechanisms, and (3) structural features and characteristics that lead to high energy-savings in buildings. This study will create enabling knowledge on thermal and optical behavior of SS-PCMs such that building temperatures can be passively regulated year-round under different climate conditions. An integrated experimental and computational program, consisting of multi-physics modeling, materials synthesis, system level integration, and building level evaluation for energy saving, will be performed to achieve the aforementioned goal. This project can transform the use of PCM by relying on radiation energy transfer processes to deliver heat, thus bypassing the low thermal conductivity problem inherent to PCMs. The low thermal conductivity of the SS-PCM foam also delays heat-loss, thus enhancing the ability of the system to remain at a desired temperature.

por.por_cntn:
Buildings are responsible for about 40% of US energy consumption; a significant fraction of this energy is needed to counter thermal losses or gains occurring through building enclosures (i.e. heating and cooling). This project aimed at developing innovative passive solar building enclosure systems that use solid-solid phase change materials (SS-PCM) with variable transparency, designed to increase thermal comfort and reduce building energy usage. An integrated experimental and numerical study, consisting of multi-physics modeling, materials synthesis, system level integration, and building level evaluation for energy saving, was performed to achieve this goal. The project outcomes are summarized in two separate categories: intellectual merits and broader impacts of the project.

 

Project outcomes related to intellectual merits: 

Through an integrated numerical and experimental study, new fundamental insights were gained on the complex conductive, radiative, and convective heat transfer phenomena occurring in SS-PCM systems for passive solar applications in buildings. This effort included the study of thin SS-PCM coatings (with and without leuco-dye), and the study of cellular SS-PCM foam systems (also with and without leuco-dye). Results confirm the beneficial impact of the SS-PCM systems attributed to their ability to dynamically change transparency to absorb the incoming solar radiation in response to the surface temperature. As a proof of concept, non-porous polymer-coated mirrors were used to evaluate the effect of SS-PCM coatings, and SS_PCM coatings with leuco-dye, on the thermo-regulating performance of our materials using a solar simulator. For walls and roofs, the SS-PCM coating on mirrors reflects a large part of solar radiation in hot days while allowing gains of solar energy in cold days. Porous SS-PCM coatings were prepared that exhibited pores ranging in size from 50 um to 500 nm. The porous SS-PCM Foam exhibit high reflectance in the UV-Vis range, comparable to a glass mirror. The high reflectance of the porous materials enabled a redesign of the system eliminating the need to use a reflective backing, instead, the porous SS-PCM materials can be used as a highly reflective and thermally insulating layer. The solar simulator tests under summer-like conditions indicated that the SS-PCM foam performed better than the non-porous white control, the bilayer system SS-FOAM-SS-PCM-dye, and the black control. This behavior is attributed to the lower thermal conductivity of the porous material compared to the non-porous/mirror systems. The solar simulator tests under winter-like conditions indicated that the bilayer system SS-FOAM-SS-PCM-dye performed comparably with the black control and better than all other coatings including the white control and the non-porous mirror-mounted coatings. The properties of the SS-FOAM-SS-PCM-dye bilayer system are attributed to a synergistic combination of the porous layer (high reflectivity and low thermal conductivity) and the thermochromic behavior of the non-porous SS-PCM layer blended with leuco-dye. Notably, the combination of a porous, highly reflective backing with a second thermochromic layer produced a thermoregulating system that can be used year-round. To the best of our knowledge this work represents the first study that enhances the fundamental understanding about the SS-PCM system?s organizational features and material characteristics that lead to high energy-savings in buildings under different climates. 

 

Project outcomes related to broader impacts:

Successful implementation of SS-PCM foam-based building enclosure materials can result in low-cost adaptive building enclosure systems that self-regulate building thermal comfort. The outcome of this study can lead to new technologies that reduce energy use in buildings, decrease dependence on fossil fuels, and improve the economic competitiveness of the United States. This study is also expected to result in benefits to diverse industries such as building materials, construction, and energy conservation. 

 

The project has provided training to 8 students in total, including undergraduate and graduate students. Of these students, 4 are female students, which accounts for 50%. Three female students were undergraduate students at WPI, one of which is currently pursuing her graduate degree in a STEM field. One-female student was an undergraduate student from Smith College, one of top-ranked liberal art private colleges. The project has successfully attracted and trained students of diverse origins and backgrounds.

Research results and findings have been and will be continuously disseminated via journal publications and conference proceedings so that the impact can reach out to different communities and disciplines worldwide. To date, five journal papers and one book chapter have been published, and two more journal manuscripts are being prepared now. In addition, results have also been disseminated in four conference presentations.
